head.title: Gallic Ode.11 Published in Philadelphia Minerva [Philadelphia, PA] (January 27, 1798). Lines 1-2 in "Gallic Ode" are taken, verbatim, from “Ode VI” in Poetical Essays (1788) p. 163, lines 1-2; line 3 is a revised version of line 3 in "Ode VI": "Boreas, sury and unkind."

lg.l: Wintry winds the forests bend,
Leaves in rustling show’rs descend,
Boreas22 God of the North wind. with his surly train,
Rages o’er the foaming main,
Rolling billows lash the shores,
Loud and long the thunder roars.
Swift driving to the rugged coast,
With dreadful crash the bark is toss’d;
The canvas parted from the mast,
Hangs tatter’d bellying in the blast;
Each gloomy cavern round replies,
Repeating loud the seamen’s cries;
Blue the dismal lightnings flash,
Falling woods tremendous crash;
From the Rock’s stupendous height,
The torrent roars in all its might,
And it its rapid progress sweeps,
Flocks, herds and shepherds to the deeps,
Plunging in the sullen flood,
The dying trav’ller shrieks aloud.
Midnight ghosts their rites perform,
Riding majestic on the storm;
By the winding valley’s stream,
Horrid the red-wing’d meteors gleam,
And from her seat obscene and foul,
Harsh screams the filthy boding owl.
Some mighty chief in arms renown’d
Shall fall and seek his native ground,
Shall sleep amid the battle’s roar,
And join the strife of shields no more.

Send round the shell!33 Drinking whisky out of small scallop shells; see, e.g., Fingal, Book V in Gaskell, The Poems of Ossian and Related Works (Edinburgh: Edinburgh UP, 1996), p. 92. the feast prolong
Strike strike the harp and strike it strong,
Though on the lofty castle’s height,
The turrets totter with the night,
Though winds and foaming billows howl,
Tho’ meteors gleam and screams the owl,
Tho’ yawning graves all open’d wide,
Let forth their shrouded ghosts to glide.
Secure within this ample roof,
Against the ruthless season proof;
Let us the present hour employ,
And give the night to love and joy,
Fill high the shell and send it round,
Let the lofty roof resound,
With mirth and song and jovial feast,
And cheer the stranger and the guest.
To-morrow’s sun, if battle call,
May see the brave and might fall,
To-day we’ve fought; our mighty foes,
With chiefs of other years repose.
From danger safe at battle’s eve,
How sweet the banquet to the brave.
Then haste! the joy of shells prepare,
Drink oblivion of your care;
Let the pleasing tales be told,
Of war and mighty men of old,
To admiring youths proclaim,
Fingal’s deeds and Ossian’s fame.44 A genearlized allusion to Macpherson’s Ossian.
Let pale fear alone controul,
The trembling fear of little soul!
